}} 'Intact Financial Corporation' '({{TSX|IFC}})' is a Canadian
insurance company; formerly the ING Group subsidiary ING Canada. It is Canada's
leading provider of property and casualty insurance (home, auto and business,
17% of the Canadian market). It also serves the
private, public and commercial (trucks, snowmobiles) vehicle market, covers
theft and vandalism, and provides other forms of business insurance.

Distribution is conducted through Intact Insurance, belairdirect, Grey Power and
BrokerLink, each specializing in a different type of insurance-related service
and product. The company operates under different subsidiaries; they include
Trafalgar Insurance Company of Canada, Equisure Financial Network Inc. and Novex
Insurance Company. Intact is considering using the $1 billion in excess capital
it has (November 2010) towards expanding its presence in Canada through
acquisitions (mid 2011 it acquired AXA Insurance's Canadian operations for $2.6
billion). Intact's investment portfolio,
containing approximately $8.7 billion in invested assets, is managed internally
by Intact Investment Management Inc.

The company has ranked well in a number of customer satisfaction surveys; In 2010 home and auto insurance subsidiary Grey Power, now GP Car
and Home ranked first in the annual JD Power and Associates customer
satisfaction study which measured customer satisfaction among private auto
insurance companies. It was also the only company in the study to receive five
out of five [http://www.jdpower.com/ratings-guide/ power circles] in each
category. Though most business comes from Ontario, Quebec, Alberta
and Nova Scotia, Intact is present in all Canadian provinces and territories
except Saskatchewan (December 2010). The company also
provides insurance brokerage services through its BrokerLink division.

Direct premiums written grew each year between 2005 and 2011 (the amount of
money customers paid for policies written during the year). They totalled $5.099
billion in 2011 which is 13% higher than in 2010 ($4.498 billion or 5.2% more
than in 2009), however only 2-5% of the growth in premiums was from organic
growth (the rest was attributable to the acquisition of AXA Canada, a move that
increased premiums by 49% in the last quarter alone). Growth in underwriting
profit was impacted by results from the personal auto insurance business ($52
million in the last quarter up from a loss of $18 million) and overall decrease
in the company's insurance claims ratio from 95.4% to 94.4% (the claims ratio is
claims payable as a percentage of income). Net income fell 7% on the year to
$465 million due to AXA Canada integration costs in the amount of $42 million.
Integration synergies with AXA Canada will increase to about $100 million by
2013. Fixed income securities dominate
investment assets (61.1% at the end of 2010, net of hedging).
categories: Companies listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange
